hotspots.label: LEGO Bird Figures
hotspots.fact: These bird figures are being pushed and pulled by forces to make them move! When you push or pull an object, you are applying a force that can change how it moves or where it goes. Engineers design toys like these LEGO birds to show us how forces work in real life.

vocabulary.definition: A push or pull that makes something move, stop, or change direction.

hotspots.label: Wheels and Axles
hotspots.fact: The green wheels on this red LEGO vehicle help it roll and move across the surface! Wheels are a simple machine that reduce friction and help objects move more easily. When wheels spin around their center point, called an axle, they turn the force from a motor into smooth rolling motion.

vocabulary.definition: A force that slows things down when two surfaces rub against each other.

hotspots.label: Electronic Control System
hotspots.fact: This LEGO robot setup uses energy from electricity to power the motor and make the machines move! Electrical energy is transferred through wires and converted into motion energy that makes the wheels and figures move. This shows how we can use different forms of energy to do work and create movement.

vocabulary.definition: The ability to make something move, change, or do work.

hotspots.label: Engineering Design Challenge
hotspots.fact: Students used LEGO bricks as materials to design and build these moving machines! Engineers follow steps to solve problems: they plan what they want to build, construct it using materials, test if it works, and improve their design. This LEGO project shows the engineering design process in action.

vocabulary.definition: A step-by-step way that engineers plan, build, test, and improve things to solve problems.
